package-manager.name: depot
package-manager.title: Httpd Web Server
package-manager.description: The Apache HTTP Server Project is an effort to develop and maintain an open-source HTTP server for modern operating systems including UNIX and Windows NT. The goal of this project is to provide a secure, efficient and extensible server that provides HTTP services in sync with the current HTTP standards.

item.para: Add dependency for "www" user
Apply regression fix for CVE-2011-3192.

Apply patch for CVE-2011-3607 (http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2011-3607). Integer overflow in the ap_pregsub function in server/util.c in the Apache HTTP Server ,when the mod_setenvif module is enabled, allows local users to gain privileges via a .htaccess file with a crafted SetEnvIf directive, in conjunction with a crafted HTTP request header, leading to a heap-based buffer overflow.

Apply patch for CVE-2011-4317 (http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2011-4317). The mod_proxy module in the Apache HTTP Server, when revision 1179239 patch is in place, does not properly interact with use of (1) RewriteRule and (2) ProxyPassMatch pattern matches for configuration of a reverse proxy, which allows remote attackers to send requests to intranet servers via a malformed URI containing an @ (at sign) character and a : (colon) character in invalid positions. NOTE: this vulnerability exists because of an incomplete fix for CVE-2011-3368.

Apply patch for CVE-2012-0031 (http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2012-0031). scoreboard.c in the Apache HTTP Server might allow local users to cause a denial of service (daemon crash during shutdown) or possibly have unspecified other impact by modifying a certain type field within a scoreboard shared memory segment, leading to an invalid call to the free function.

Apply patch for CVE-2012-0053 (http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2012-0053). protocol.c in the Apache HTTP Server does not properly restrict header information during construction of Bad Request (aka 400) error documents, which allows remote attackers to obtain the values of HTTPOnly cookies via vectors involving a (1) long or (2) malformed header in conjunction with crafted web script.
